description: A hearty and flavorful dish where tender yam leaves are simmered in a thick, creamy, and nutty groundnut sauce. The slightly robust and earthy flavor of the yam leaves pairs beautifully with the rich, savory notes of the groundnuts, creating a luxurious vegetable stew that is both deeply satisfying and highly nutritious.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: This dish is a celebration of utilizing the entire yam plantâ€”the tubers as a carbohydrate and the leaves as a vegetable. It is a common preparation in regions where yams are cultivated. Combining these leaves with groundnut sauce elevates a simple foraged green into a protein-rich, main-course stew. It exemplifies the 'zero-waste' philosophy and deep agricultural knowledge inherent in Ugandan food culture, turning a humble ingredient into a culinary delight.

ingredients.name: Fresh Yam Leaves
ingredients.notes: About 10-12 cups. Young, tender leaves are best. Must be washed thoroughly and chopped.

ingredients.name: Baking Soda
ingredients.notes: A tiny pinch to help soften the yam leaves and retain their green color.

steps.instruction: Bring 2 cups of water to a boil in a large pot. Add the pinch of baking soda and the chopped yam leaves.
Boil the yam leaves for 5-7 minutes until they are tender and have lost any potential sharpness or itchiness. Drain the water and set the leaves aside.

cooking_indicators.visual: Leaves become a vibrant, darker green and are soft to the touch.

steps.instruction: In the same pot, add the chopped onion and 1/2 cup of water. Cook over medium heat until the onion is soft and translucent, about 5 minutes.
Add the chopped tomatoes and cook for another 5 minutes until they break down and form a thick sauce.
In a separate bowl, gradually whisk the groundnut paste with 1.5 cups of water until you have a very smooth, lump-free, creamy liquid.
Pour the smooth groundnut mixture into the pot with the tomato and onion base. Stir to combine.
Bring the sauce to a gentle simmer. Let it cook for 5-10 minutes, stirring frequently to prevent burning, until it thickens slightly.
Add the pre-boiled yam leaves and salt to the pot. Stir well to coat the leaves in the sauce.
Reduce the heat to low, cover, and let it simmer for another 10 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld and the leaves to fully absorb the nutty flavor. Stir occasionally.

cooking_indicators.texture: The sauce should be thick and creamy, coating the leaves thoroughly.

steps.instruction: If the stew is too thick, add a little more hot water to reach your desired consistency. Serve hot.

serving_suggestions: Serve as a main dish with a staple carbohydrate like Posho (Ugali), Matoke, or Cassava. The thick, rich sauce is perfect for scooping. It can also be served with steamed rice or sweet potatoes.
